content.description: This is a great slab problem that is worth the headache. A little perplexing to get situated on the wall, but it puts a smile on your face when you top it out.
content.location: This problem is on the east side of the boulder and climbs the short slab to a sloping finish. The holds are there if you look hard enough! Stand start just to the right of the big rock on the ground and work your slab magic... remember, friends don't let friends climb slab!

content.description:
The Sds ups the grade and begins low left (and matched [Chip]) on an incut sidepull/undercling. Bust right to a decent crimp and then heel on the starting hold. The crux move is reaching over to the starting jug of

Get Over It

proper. Distinguished from a right SDS version. Thanks Chip.
content.location: Starts down and left of GOI Stand.

content.description: This problem is a classic for the area, attracting hard climbers simply because there is nothing in the area quite like it. It is a great boulder problem that offers a little of everything. Powerful moves, to small crimps, to perfect slopers.
content.location: Start matched on an edge roughly at face height, bust a powerful move up and right to a sloper, move out right to bad crimps, and then onto bad slopers to topout up and right.

content.description: Sit down as low as you can and slap and squeeze your way up the bulging arete to a slab top-out.
content.location:
Left-most arete on the front side of the

Double Trouble

boulder.  Right of the tree.

content.description: Start matched on an edge about face height in the middle of the boulder. Make a difficult throw to a sloper up and right. Move up and left to topout.
content.location:
This problem lies in the middle of the north face and shares the same start as "

Get Over It

".

content.description: This is not such a classic line. It has some good jugs to hang on for those looking to warm up for the harder lines the boulder has to offer.
content.location: This problem is located on the Northwest prow of the boulder. It starts low on the far NW side of the boulder and climbs around the prow on obvious jugs. Watch out for spiderwebs as you turn onto the face.

pathTokens: North Fork of the St. Vrain River
